params.text:
Telephone

Answer a Call Part 2

Language in Action

• Clarifying: Asking to repeat
  • Strategies - Mirroring
  • Ending the call

Today we will focus on essential telephone skills to enhance your customer interactions.

You'll learn how to:

1. Clarifying: Asking to repeat: Learn how to politely ask for clarification when you don't understand a caller.

  2. Strategies – Mirroring: Discover the power of mirroring in building rapport and understanding caller needs.

  3. Ending the call: Master effective techniques for concluding calls professionally and positively.
Clarifying: Asking To Repeat: Flashcards

dialogs.answer: Use this when you didn't hear something clearly.
Another way to say "Sorry?" when you didn't hear something.
Use this when you want someone to repeat something.
Use this when you don't understand what the person means.
Use this when you didn't hear or understand something.
Use this when you want the person to speak more slowly.

The time of the meeting

The date of the meeting

params.text: Please listen to the following telephone conversation and answer the questions:

Anthony: Hello, Bryan. This is Anthony. Can you tell me the time of the meeting tomorrow?

Bryan: Hi Anthony. Yes, the meeting is at 10 o’clock.

Anthony: Sorry?

Bryan: Ten o’clock.

Anthony: Ten o’clock. Okay, thanks.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What does Anthony want to do?
answers:
Change his appointment

Cancel his appointment

Make a new appointment

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What day does Anthony want to change his appointment to?
Question 3 of 3: What does Bryan do to show that he understands Anthony?
answers:
He repeats the day Anthony wants to change to

He says "Thank you"

He hangs up the phone

params.text: Please listen to the following telephone conversation and answer the questions:

Anthony: Hello Bryan, it’s Anthony. I need to change my appointment.

Bryan: No problem, Anthony. When did you want to change it to?

Anthony: I want to change it to Thursday.

Bryan: Thursday?

Anthony: Yes, Thursday.

Bryan: Okay, Thursday. Let me check.

dialogs.answer: Use this phrase when you have finished discussing everything important.

dialogs.text: Right, well, thanks for your help.
dialogs.answer: Use this phrase to thank the other person and end the call.
A polite way to end the call, especially if you are the one who answered the phone.
A casual way to end a call with someone you know well.
Use this phrase when you have finished discussing all the necessary points.
A polite way to end the call and let the other person know you are finishing.

params.textField: Finish talking about *everything*. Then say "goodbye" or "*talk* to you later". You can also say "thank you for *calling*".

params.textField: It's *important* to say goodbye. You can say "bye" or "see you *later*". Also, say "thank you" to the *other* person.

params.textField: Be *friendly* when you *finish* the call. Say "bye" and *something* nice, like "have a good day".

metadata.title: Ending the call Drag the Words

params.text: Read each question carefully and choose the BEST answer:

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: What should you do if you don't understand what someone says on the phone?
answers:
Ask them to repeat it.

Hang up the phone.

Say "yes" and pretend you understand.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: What is mirroring?
answers:
Repeating what the other person says.

Copying the other person's clothes.

Saying something different to the other person.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: Which phrase is best for ending a phone call?
answers:
"Goodbye. See you later."

"Hello?"

"I like your shirt."

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: Why is it important to ask someone to repeat what they said?
answers:
To understand what they said.

To be polite.

To make them happy.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: What can you do to show the other person you understand them?
answers:
Repeat what they said.

Sing a song.

Eat a sandwich.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: When should you say "thank you" on the phone?
answers:
At the end of the call.

At the beginning of the call.

In the middle of the call.
